title: Iraq starts anti-IS Anbar offensive
desc: Pro-government forces in Iraq launch an operation to drive Islamic State (IS) out of the western province of Anbar days after the fall of Ramadi.

title: India heatwave toll passes 1000
desc: The death toll in the heatwave sweeping India passes 1000 with temperatures nearing 50C (122F) in some areas.

title: How Arctic ozone hole was avoided
desc: The Antarctic ozone hole would have been 40% bigger and a hole over the Arctic would have opened up if ozone-depleting chemicals had not been phased out according to research.

title: Trader accused over Libor was 'greedy'
desc: Former City trader Tom Hayes is accused of being dishonest and manipulative and a ringmaster in his alleged attempts to rig Libor rates a court hears.

title: Cleveland police agree to US reforms
desc: The Cleveland police department which has been criticised for aggressive tactics against African Americans agrees to strict federal reforms.

title: Runaway mafia boss held in Brazil
desc: An Italian organised crime boss convicted for more than 20 murders has been caught in Brazil after 31 years on the run.

title: Malaysia exhumes mass 'migrant' graves
desc: Malaysia exhumes bodies suspected to be migrants buried in 139 grave sites as fresh details of alleged human trafficking camps emerge.

title: Air France flight 'missed mountain'
desc: An Air France plane with 37 people on board narrowly missed hitting central Africa's highest mountain in early May French investigators say.

title: Boy guilty of Austrian terror plot
desc: A 14-year-old boy is convicted of terrorism offences in Austria including a bomb plot potentially targeting a railway station in Vienna.

title: Volcano erupts on Galapagos island
desc: A volcanic eruption on one of the Galapagos Islands potentially puts Charles Darwin's evolution ecosystem at risk.

title: Chinese navy to focus on 'open seas'
desc: China announces its strategy to focus the navy beyond its borders into open water in a military strategy document.

title: Heavy rains put Houston underwater
desc: At least three people have died in the Houston area after major flooding and tornadoes swept across the southern US and Mexico.

title: VIDEO: Life inside a Ukrainian ghost village
desc: Eastern Ukraine is enduring a second summer of conflict as a ceasefire nominally in place since February has failed to stop the violence in areas around Donetsk airport.

title: VIDEO: Aerial footage of swamped Houston
desc: The mayor of Houston has asked the governor of Texas to declare the city a disaster area after flash floods left at least two people dead and turned streets into rivers.

title: VIDEO: Stolen art returns home to Rome
desc: The United States returns Italian antiquities stolen in past decades and recovered in the US to Italy.

title: VIDEO: Will India's lethal heatwave continue?
desc: A heatwave sweeping India has killed more than 500 people with most of the deaths in the southern states of Telangana and Andhra Pradesh.

title: VIDEO: Moment BBC Women's Footballer named
desc: Nigeria and Liverpool forward Asisat Oshoala has been named as the BBC Women's Footballer of the Year.

title: VIDEO: Man covered in bees sets record
desc: A man in China Gao Bingguo sets a new world record after coating his body with bees.

title: VIDEO: Is Jordan next target for Islamic State?
desc: As fears grow that Jordan could be Islamic States's next target the country has been redoubling its efforts to confront the extremist threat on its borders and inside the country.

title: VIDEO: Meet the militias battling IS in Iraq
desc: Earlier this month militants from Islamic State seized the Iraqi city of Ramadi with its fall seen as a major capitulation by the Iraqi Army.

title: Ukraine's civilians living on frontline
desc: Fergal Keane travels to Pisky on Ukraine's frontline to discover why an elderly couple refuse to leave their destroyed and deserted hometown.

title: Islamic State PR gloss masks Iraqi forces' gains
desc: John Simpson: Fear and PR jihadists' strongest card

title: Should animals be given human rights?
desc: A New York court is considering whether chimps are legal persons - and whether animals should be granted the same rights as humans?

title: Solar Impulse awaits 'moment of truth'
desc: In what will be its greatest challenge yet the zero-fuel aeroplane Solar Impulse will soon try to fly non-stop from China to Hawaii - a journey of more than 8000km across the Pacific Ocean.

title: Nash's ground-breaking ideas
desc: John Nash the US mathematician who has died aged 86 made an enduring contribution to his field writes maths lecturer John Moriarty.

title: Who are Israelâ€™s Ethiopian Jews?
desc: Protests over the beating of an Ethiopian Israeli soldier have thrown the spotlight on the Ethiopian Jewish community in Israel writes Prof Yossi Mekelberg.

title: Barenboim designs 'radical' new piano
desc: Pianist and conductor Daniel Barenboim has unveiled a new type of piano which he says is radically different to the standard concert grand.

title: Atwood book goes in 'Future Library'
desc: Margaret Atwood becomes the first of 100 authors to enter a manuscript into the Future Library a project collecting works not to be published until 2114.

title: Amazon changes sales reporting
desc: Amazon the global online retailer is changing the way it records European sales in a move that could see it paying more tax.

title: Charter to buy Time Warner Cable
desc: Charter Communications agrees to buy media giant Time Warner Cable in a deal which values the company at $78.7bn.

title: Apple design guru Jony Ive promoted
desc: Apple promotes British designer Jony Ive to chief design officer according to reports.

title: Periscope arrives on Android
desc: Twitter's live video streaming app Periscope is being launched on Google's Android platform exactly two months after its debut in the Apple store.

title: BB King's death to be investigated
desc: Blues legend BB King's death is investigated after his daughters claim he was deliberately given medication to induce diabetic shock.

title: Actor Sharif has Alzheimer's disease
desc: Actor Omar Sharif who starred Lawrence of Arabia and Doctor Zhivago in the 1960s is diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease.

title: 'Loud wakeup call' over rare dolphin
desc: The smallest and rarest marine dolphin in the world could be extinct within 15 years if protection is not stepped up according to research.

title: Coastal farm sold to National Trust
desc: Parts of the iconic Great Orme headland in north Wales are safeguarded for the future after being bought by the National Trust.

title: Teen obesity 'link to bowel cancer'
desc: Being overweight or obese in adolescence is linked to a greater risk of bowel cancer later in life a study suggests.

title: Depression makes heart failure worse
desc: People with heart failure must be screened for signs of depression and offered counselling scientists say.

title: Nadal and Djokovic through in Paris
desc: Nine-time champion Rafael Nadal and world number one Novak Djokovic both make winning starts in the French Open

title: Bayliss named as England head coach
desc: England appoint Australian Trevor Bayliss 52 as their new coach succeeding Peter Moores who was sacked in early May.

title: The falcon hospital of Qatar
desc: Hunting with falcons is a popular sport in the Gulf - and Qatar's capital city Doha has a specialist hospital where injured birds are treated.

title: Europe's next cheap holiday destination?
desc: As no-frills airlines start flying to the Azores Simon Calder asks whether the islands in the Atlantic Ocean could become the next big holiday destination.

title: Meet YouTube's 8-bit movie makers
desc: A team which recreates popular films as 8-bit video games is attracting millions of views on YouTube.

title: 'Dancing Man' parties in Los Angeles
desc: A British man who attracted global support after fat-shaming images of him were posted online attends a party in his honour in Los Angeles.

title: 'Spike' in Nigeria suicide attacks
desc: The UN children's agency says there has been an alarming increase in the number of suicide attacks in northern Nigeria.

title: Australia tampon tax under fire
desc: An online petition calling for the scrapping of Australian states' taxation of tampons is backed by Treasurer Joe Hockey.

title: 'Truffle thief' death trial begins
desc: French farmer Laurent Rambaud goes on trial accused of killing a suspected truffle thief on his land but claims he felt threatened by the intruder.

title: Colombia Farc leader 'died in raid'
desc: A senior Farc rebel commander Roman Ruiz is believed to be among five Colombian guerrilla fighters killed in a bombing raid on Monday.

title: Iran trial begins for US reporter
desc: The trial of a Washington Post journalist detained in Iran for almost 10 months on charges that include espionage opens behind closed doors in Tehran.

title: Violent Baltimore sees less arrests
desc: The number of arrests made by Baltimore police in May has plummeted as shootings and homicides have dramatically increased.

title: Family man dies at Dignitas centre
desc: A British father-of-three who feared he would be paralysed by an inoperable tumour dies at the Dignitas centre in Switzerland.

title: UK 'will not accept migrant quotas'
desc: The UK will not be part of any EU plan to relocate thousands of African migrants currently in Italy and Greece the international development secretary says.

title: Victims of ID theft 'up by a third'
desc: The number of people falling victim to identity theft in the UK rises by almost a third in the first three months of 2015 figures from fraud prevention agency Cifas show.

title: Broadmoor nurse sold 'killer' stories
desc: A mental health nurse at Broadmoor high security hospital admits selling stories about patients to newspaper journalists.

title: Eurovision Song Contest: In pictures
desc: Celebrations at the 60th anniversary show in Vienna

title: Fish fruit and veg in S Korea's markets
desc: Ben Weller has been taking pictures of South Korea's markets

title: Your pictures: Looking in
desc: Readers' images on the theme of looking in

title: Week in pictures: 16-22 May 2015
desc: From around the world - 16-22 May

title: In pictures: Women of Hargeisa
desc: Alison Baskerville's photos of women in Somaliland

desc: The 40 year conflict that remains unresolved

title: How male and female bathing suits got smaller and smaller
desc: How swimwear has changed over a century

title: Photo challenge: 12 by 12
desc: Tasks to develop your photo skills

title: Why I started a 'tampon tax' campaign
desc: Why I started a campaign to get rid of the 'tampon tax'

title: Inside Jordan's fight against extremism
desc: Inside Jordan's fight against home-grown extremism

title: Where did Charlie Charlie Challenge come from?
desc: Millions online follow supernatural craze - but it isn't what it seems

title: Why do people waste so much time at the office?
desc: Why do people waste so much time at the office?

title: India marital rape victims' lonely battle for justice
desc: Seeking justice for marital rape in India

title: Will truckers lose out to software?
desc: Is the lorry driver of the future a piece of software?
